div.p: 1. VI:Mr Parish came to the Office again for Mr Canning’s Note. It had already been received from the President’s and sent to him— Parish afterwards brought it back, with Mr Canning’s alterations which were only of a few words— Baron Stackelberg came upon the subject of his Note, and complaint— Mr Brent had called upon him, and had also seen the Mayor; who had received from the Constable complained of an account of the incident differing in some particulars, from that which Stackelberg had received from his Servants— The Constable says he was invited into the House. The Baron said he would make further enquiry into the facts— That he should not now have complained if something in the same sort had not happened to him, once or twice before, which he had not noticed; and that he wished now to make no unnecessary difficulty; but would readily withdraw his note if desired— He asked also for a copy of the provisions in the Act of Congress, requiring that foreign Ministers should furnish lists of their families, and servants at the Department of State—with which he had not been acquainted. I received a despatch from H. Middleton our Minister at St. Petersburg, dated 8/20 August relating entirely to the North-West Coast Controversy. — The Baron de Tuyl is coming out as Minister from Russia, charged with a proposal for negotiating on the Subject— Speransky, now Governor General of Siberia told Middleton that they had at first thought of declaring the Northern Pacific Ocean a Mare Clausum— But afterwards took the 100 Italian Miles, from the 30 leagues in the Treaty of Utrecht, which is an exclusion only from a fishery, and not from Navigation. I took this Letter which is most confidential to the President, and desired him after reading it to return it to me, that it may not be exposed to be brought before the public, which Mr Middleton requests that it may not. The President read me a paragraph, of the draft of his Message, which he had begun to prepare. It related to the Proclamation of 24. August, and intercourse with the British Colonies in America. I asked him if he would not think it admirable to notice in the message, the latitude of Construction which was given to the term West-Indies in the act of Congress of 6. May by the Proclamation— He said he would— I left Cards at Strother’s for Mr Harris, Mr Morel and a Mr Cox, who brought me a Letter of recommendation from S. Ewing of Philadelphia, and is applying for an appointment as a member of the Legislative Council in Florida— A card also for General Winder. Mr T. B. Johnson returned from Mr Frye’s; Mrs Adams received a Letter from our Son Charles who was sick at Quincy— Evening walks and Chess.

2. VI:Commodore Porter came and introduced to me Mr T. R. Eldredge, who applies for the appointment of Consul at Lima, and brings numerous recommendations in his favour— He has resided there some years. I told him that no appointments would be made for South-America, before the Meeting of Congress— At the Office, Mr Cowper of Norfolk, came to enquire again about the case of Mr James Youngs five Slaves, taken during the late War, carried into Jamaica, condemned and sold, and bought in by his own agent. Or rather restored to him on bond, before condemnation, and the penalty of the bond paid afterwards— I looked up and examined the papers which had passed between me and the British Government on the subject, and found that there was no claim of Mr Young upon the British Government, which could be diplomatically sustained— Mr Young has obtained a formal receipt from Mr Lushington of the receipt in the British Treasury, of the money; the proceeds of the sale of the Slaves— This the British Government in their correspondence with me, contended could not be, because it was contrary to an Act of Parliament, prohibiting the Sale of any captured Slaves. I told Mr Cowper, that Mr Young might have a good claim against the British Government for the money levied upon him contrary to their own Law, but that we could
not sustain it on national grounds, because the Slaves had been taken at Sea, and condemned and sold as Prize of War. He said that was his own opinion— I added that if Mr Young should pursue his claim, Mr Rush would give him all the assistance within his power and competency— We had company to dinner. The commissioners White, King, and Tazewell— Major L. Austin, D. Brent, J. A. Dix, F. C. Gray, H. Johnson, Mr and Mrs Orne, T. Watkins, and Mr and Mrs Wirt. There had also been invited General Brown, Mr and Mrs Brown of Louisiana, Mr Cowper, Mr and Mrs Frye, Mr E. Livingston, Captain Patterson and General Winder, who came not— We were twenty at table. The dinner was pleasant with the exception of one incident. In a desultory conversation upon wines, Mr Tazewell, asserted, and perseveringly insisted, that Tokay was a species of Rhenish Wine; after insisting to the contrary for sometime in perfect good humour and civility, as he still persisted, in the warmth of the collision, I said, “why, you never drank a drop of Tokai in your life”— I set this down as a token of self-disapprobation for having said it— Tazewell made no reply; but looked hurt— The conversation turned upon other topics; and as leaving the table he went away, without returning with the rest of the company to the drawing room— I have no good apology to make to myself for this incivility; for that Tazewell himself is not sparing of feelings in the clash of conversation, and had been much otherwise even at this dinner is no justification to me.

3. VI:15—Mr Thomas B. Johnson, my wife’s brother left us this morning to return to New-Orleans— He has partially recovered his health, and that has induced him to go back. He went this day to Baltimore thence to proceed to New-York, and there to embark in the Steam-Ship Robert Fulton, advertised to sail this day week, for New-Orleans— Heard Mr Little; in the Morning from Proverbs 10.29.— “The way of the Lord is strength to the upright: but destruction shall be to the workers of iniquity”— A moral discourse— After the morning service he gave a short Lecture of about fifteen minutes, introductory to a course, to be delivered in the same manner. He said it was a practice customary in many of the Unitarian Societies in England— That it had been observed that the Unitarians were better informed than other Sects of Christians, and that it was desirable they should be careful to preserve that reputation— He laid down an extensive plan upon which he proposed to follow up this course; and said that in his Lecture next given he should begin with a historical account of the Scriptures. His course is to be historical, geographical and critical; a mass of information more suitable to be communicated by Lectures, than by Sermons— I thought his plan a very good one, but that it would be more profitably pursued, by devoting to it one of the Services of the day, than by distracting the attention from the morning Sermon to a different subject for meditation— The afternoon discourse, was from Matthew 5.45. “That ye may be the children of your father which is in Heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil, and on the good, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust.”— The precept of returning good for evil is one of the most exalted and sublime lessons of Christianity; and perhaps the most difficult of all its doctrines to carry into practice— There is little of that sort of Christianity in the world— Would there were more— Mrs Adams has taken the late Mr Meigs’s pew in the second Presbyterian church; and with the family went there this morning, and again in the Evening to hear Mr Baker— I employed the Evening in making up Mrs Meigs’s papers to send to England.

4. VI:30.Mr Eldredge was again here this Morning, about his application for the appointment of Consul at Lima— I was teized with his importunities; and when he asked me if I could inform him whether it was likely the appointment of Consul for Lima, would be soon made, I peevishly answered; it will not be made until the meeting of Congress as I have told you “before”— He asked no more questions and soon left me— He that is slow to anger is better than the mighty; and he that ruleth his Spirit than he that taketh a City— George rode up to
Rockville, to visit Johnson Hellen— Baron Stackelberg was at the Office, with a written narrative by his Valet de Chambre, Bede of the attempt made by the Constable, Waters to arrest a woman servant in the Baron’s House— He declares that Waters entered the house though forbidden by him to enter; which seems a more probable Story than that of Waters that he was invited in— I promised the Baron to make further enquiry, and that he should have eventually satisfaction— F. C. Gray came to enquire concerning the character of J. Connell, who had been recommended to his father as Agent for prosecuting claims on the French Government— I gave Connell an excellent character, recommending him in the strongest terms as a man intelligent, upright and trusty— Mr Gray enquired whether Connell was commissioned by the Government in his agency— I told him he was not. He was a private Agent for several Insurance Companies having claims; and Mr Gallatin had been requested to give him any Official assistance that might be proper. Mr Gray had also enquiries to make for papers relating to his father’s claims upon France— Mr Barber a Priest who has been some years attached to the Roman Catholic Seminary here, and to the College at Georgetown, is going to minister at a Church in Claremont, New-Hampshire, of which he is a native— He goes through Boston, and came to ask me for a Letter of Introduction to my father, whom he wishes to visit. I promised to give him one— I answered a Letter from W. P. Duval Governor of Florida, and commenced upon the Resolution of reading no Newspapers at the Office; excepting only the National Intelligencer of the day— To avoid the waste of Time— Baron Stackelberg spent the Evening with us— I had received on Saturday a Letter from E. Cruft enclosing a Bill upon the Navy Department, endorsed to and by him— I presented it this Morning to Mr Homans the Chief Clerk— It was accepted, payable at thirty days. Mr Cruft desired immediate payment; but Homans preferred waiting for the arrival of Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy to order it. He is expected in two or three days.

5. VI: A Mr T. H. Howland of Alexandria, formerly of New Bedford came to the Office to solicit the appointment of Consul at Barbadoes— He had no recommendations. Mr E. J. Lee: The Clerk of the Circuit Court there, came again about his fees for furnishing a list of Causes in the Court under a Resolution of the Senate— I made a draft of an Answer to Mr Canning’s Letter upon the Intercourse with the British American Colonies, and sent it to the President for Consideration— George returned home from his visit to Rockville. Mr and Mrs Smith dined at Mr Frye’s, Mrs. Adams, Mary Hellen, and George passed the Evening there. I was at home, and wrote Letters to E. Cruft about his Bill of Exchange, and to J. A. Smith at London, enclosing to him Mrs Meigs’s papers. Mr Crawford returned this Evening with his family, from his Summer excursion to Georgia. He has been absent four Months.

6. VI: I called this morning at the Office of the Comptroller Anderson, to enquire about the settlement of the Account of the late Mr Meigs. His widow is going shortly to Philadelphia, to pass the Winter with her Son, and yesterday was at my house, and spoke again on the subject— I asked Anderson if the Letter I had last left with him, would not be a sufficient voucher for the Settlement— He said it would not; there being other documents impairing the conclusiveness of the favourable inference which might have been drawn from it. He still professed however a disposition to do all in his power to effect the settlement, to the satisfaction of Mrs Meigs— I mentioned to him the correspondence with Mr Canning with reference to his Circular to the Collectors of the Customs, explanatory of the President’s Proclamation, of 24 August last— He said Mr Parish had been several times to him, to expostulate on the subject; but he had told him, it must be discussed with the Department of State. I mentioned that with regard to the removal of restrictions on exportation, they had not been so liberal in the West-Indies
as we have been here; and promised to send him Hollingsworth’s Letter and Woodley’s opinion. At the Office, Mr Robert N. Johnston of Baltimore; brought me Letters of introduction, from Mr. Evans of that place, and from Mr William Taylor at Mexico— Johnston himself came last August from Mexico; where he has been some years. His accounts of the political situation of that Country agree with those received from Taylor— The Emperor Yturbide, is evidently the shallowest of the military adventurers of the School of Napoleon, who in the present age have had the fortune and the folly to assume a crown— He can scarcely escape from it with his life—and it is scarcely imaginable that he should be suffered to wear it a year— He has no revenue; and while he exists only by levying forced loans, his only projected resource is to borrow thirty Millions of dollars in England, France and the United States— His Coronation was a miserable pageant of Mock Magnificence, of which the Crowns of himself and his wife, made of gilded tin, and beset with borrowed jewels were characteristic symbols— Yet for the performance of this farce he was obliged to levy a forced loan of six hundred thousand dollars— Mr Calhoun came, with a recommendation of a Mr Bowie, for the office of District Attorney, in West Florida, and of Mr Cox, as a member of the Legislative Council, in the place of Dr Bronaugh, dead at Pensacola, of the yellow fever— I began a Letter to the Spanish Minister Anduaga, in answer to his complaint on the capture of the Palmyra. We attended an Evening dancing party at Mr Calhoun’s— Met there Mr and Mrs Wingate, Mr and Mrs Orne, Mr and Mrs Agg, and Mr Cox, whom Calhoun introduced to me— Agg is an Englishman; now joint Editor with M’Kenney of the Washington Republican— He spoke to me of the righteous cause which they are maintaining, and of the extraordinary success of their paper.

7. VI:30. The day after I dismissed John B. Colvin from the Department of State, I saw his hand in the Washington City Gazette— He has since commenced a series of numbers under the Editorial parts of that paper, headed the Presidential Question; each of two of three Columns— Five numbers have appeared, written in Colvin’s best manner, professing to give a delineation of my character, and scanning my pretensions to the Presidency. They present me in caricature, and touch upon every thing true, and every thing false that can be made to resemble truth, which could degrade me in the popular opinion. They are written with just so much regard to truth, as to seize on single facts, to which a suspicious colouring may be given, from which a whole tale of falsehood is fabricated and asserted as fact to exhibit me as a base and despicable character. Between three and four years ago, Colvin attempted to fawn himself into my favour, by eulogizing me in newspapers— He published a characteristic Portrait of me, so highly charged, that on being informed it was written by him, I requested him to abstain from any such publications having any personal reference to me whatever— That if he inclined to political newspaper discussion, and would defend and vindicate any measures of the administration which might be assailed, his labours would be acceptable, but that I wanted no personal panegyrist— He continued to cringe however, and to work windingly for my good graces, but besides the warning of his old treachery to Robert Smith, the more I saw of him the more reason I had for distrusting him; and I never placed any confidence in him— He had shrewdness enough to after a year or two of ineffectual parasitical courtship, to discover his failure, and among my present characteristics enumerates, a lurking and distrustful suspicion in the eye— He would occasionally endeavor indirectly to get sight of the secret diplomatic documents but they were kept out of his reach— His absences from the Office, and neglect of his duties, in the mean time kept increasing with his habits of intemperance till they could no longer be
tolerated. I had long been aware that it must ultimately come to this; and have been gradually breaking his hold from the Office till he could be dismissed without inconvenience— I know that from that moment he would become the bitterest of my revilers; and of the whole tribe he is the only one, who can be instigated to injure me, by revenge— A comparison between his Portrait of 1819 and his Caricature now, would be curious, as marking the depraved ingenuity of unprincipled intellect. His five numbers on the Presidential Question, teem with falsehoods. I wrote this morning and sent to Gales and Seaton, a short paper containing a direct contradiction of two among the basest of those falsehoods— I did this in deference to feelings in my family more sensitive to such Slanders than my own— No man in America has made his way through showers of ribaldry and invective of this character, more frequent and various than I have breasted— A new storm of them has in the last eighteen months burst upon me; and will rage, until every indication of a party holding my name up as a Candidate for the Presidency, shall have vanished— I received a Letter from Joseph R. Ingersoll at Philadelphia, stating that a new Commission would issue from the Court to take over again my first deposition in the case of Harris vs Lewis, on account of some informality, real or apprehended in the taking of it before— I was at the President’s and met Mr Calhoun there— The President directed a Cabinet-Meeting for one O’Clock to-morrow, to consider my draft of an answer to Mr Canning’s Letter, upon the Comptroller’s Circular and the Colonial Intercourse— He read me a paragraph that he had prepared to insert in the Message, recommending to Congress the Institution of a tribunal in Florida, to carry into effect the stipulation in the 9th. Article of the Florida Treaty— The Governor of the Arkansas Territory James Miller, has requested leave of absence for the next Summer. I took his Letter to the President, who directed me to answer, that he might have leave of absence, for such term, as would not be incompatible with the convenience of the Public Service; for which the President expected he would make effectual provision— I took Mr Hollingsworth’s Letter at the President’s; and wrote to the Spanish Minister Anduaga, in answer to his complaint in the case of the Palmyra— Mrs. Adams was unwell; and confined to her chamber.

8. VI. Cabinet Meeting at the Presidents, at One O’Clock— Present Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun— The Attorney General is at Baltimore— Mr Canning’s Letter was read by the President; and I read the draft of my answer. Mr Canning’s complaint is two fold— One that while the Act of Parliament levies the same duties in our importations to the Colonies whether in American or in British Vessels, and admits direct importations in American Vessels of the Products of the whole United States, our Proclamation, as explained by the Comptroller’s Letter, levies foreign tonnage duties, and the ten per Cent additional on merchandise, and limits the importations to West India Products from the West-Indies, and to North American Products from North-America, when imported in British Vessels. And he argues, that in the principle of reciprocity for opening the intercourse, Great Britain has a right to claim, that we should impose no restriction upon the British Navigation, employed in it, which is not a specific counterpart of a like restriction, upon our Navigation in the Act of Parliament. My Answer, alleges a want of Authority in the Executive to remove the Tonnage and discriminating duties; and denies the principle that we should be confined to specific counterparts of any restrictions in the Act of Parliament— It enumerates the various restrictions upon our Navigation, as admitted under the Act of Parliament, and says that our restrictions may perhaps not be sufficient to counteract them. Mr Crawford expressed a doubt whether the second point of Canning’s complaint was completely answered by my draft— He said that as to the tonnage and other
discriminating duties it was clear, that the President had no authority to repeal them, but he might remove the restriction upon the importations, so as to admit the Productions of all the Colonies, from any of the Colonial Ports— And he inclined to the opinion that the discriminating duties were sufficient to countervail in favour of our Navigation the British restrictions— This however is altogether conjectural— Mr Calhoun enquired, whether we had any facts, and knew how the late opening of the intercourse had operated— I had nothing but Hollingsworth’s Letters, and Mr Crawford had nothing— There was some discussion as to the effect of admitting in British Vessels West India produce from North-America and North-American produce from the West-Indies. Mr Calhoun remarked upon the advantage it would give in making up assorted Cargoes, and I observed that its effect must be estimated in connection with the latitude of exportation which we have allowed to British vessels without restriction; while they lay our vessels under export bonds, to land their own Cargoes exclusively in the United States— Mr Crawford finally said, and all agreed that no alteration of the Proclamation would be advisable; the Meeting of Congress approaching now within a Month; and it being evident that the regulation of the intercourse with the British Colonies, must be a subject of negotiation between the Governments— The President suggested the propriety of omitting the passage of my draft which intimated that the counter-restrictions of the Proclamation might perhaps not be sufficient, but consented that it should remain, modified to say they were surely not more than sufficient— My draft of a Letter to the Spanish Minister Anduaga, on the case of the Palmyra, was also read and approved— The new Chargé d’Affaires from Portugal Constancio arrived and while I was at the President’s, left at the Department of State the Letter to me, introducing him, from the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs. It is dated in February last, and contains the proposals of alliance, and of a Commission for Claims, of Portuguese Subjects upon the Government of the United States, which had been broached by the Abbé Correa, and discussed with Mr Amado-Grehon. He left three Letters from the King of Portugal to the United States; one of which was the notification of recall of the Abbe Corréa. Mr Brent sent these Letters over to the President’s while we were there in Meeting. After returning to the Office I wrote a short Answer to the Spanish Minister Anduaga, to his Note upon the Court where the claims of Spanish Floridians under the 9th. Article of the Treaty are to be tried— Mr and Mrs R. Cutts were here and spent the Evening with our Ladies; but I did not see them. I was reading the second Volume of Walpole’s Memoires, which is particularly interesting by the account of the trial and execution of Byng— More atrocious murders have doubtless been committed— But none in which factious intrigues more basely combined with popular excitement and prejudice. Chess with W. S. Smith.

9. VI— My short Note to Gales and Seaton, exposing two of the many falsehoods in Colvin’s abusive papers on the Presidential question, was published this Morning in the National Intelligencer, as a Communication, and a reply appeared in the Washington Gazette of this Evening reasserting them, adding a number more of falsehoods, and redoubling scurrilous invectives— At the Office, the Count de Menou Chargé d’Affaires of France, called, just returned from his excursion of several weeks to Philadelphia— He said he had received Letters of 13 Septr from the Baron Hyde de Neuville, who has been received with great distinction by the King— Every member of the Legation, has been noticed by some mark of favour— An ordinance issued for carrying into effect the Convention, from the first of October, but it has not been ratified— Menou said that they probably wished to take time, and consult the chambers of Commerce to act deliberately with regard to the ratification.
Menou said that Hersant would come out in The Six Brothers; a vessel which was to sail from Havre for New-York in October; but he did not appear to expect that he would bring the ratified Convention. That is ultimately to be brought out by Bresson— The demur I have no doubt is upon the Separate Article, proposed by De Neuville himself, and which they will probably not ratify— Mr Calhoun came with a Letter from a friend recommending W. F. Steele for District Attorney in West Florida— I received also a Letter from Steele himself soliciting the appointment— In consequence of the suggestion yesterday of Mr Crawford, I added two short paragraphs to the draft of answer to Mr Canning on the Colonial Intercourse— Received Letters from my Sons John and Charles. Answered the letter, and also the Letter, received the day before yesterday from Joseph R. Ingersoll. Reading further in Walpole’s Memoires, on secret History of the British Administrations from 1750 to 1760. I find in them many things that remind me of the present state of things here. The public History of all Countries, and all ages, is but a sort of mask, richly coloured— The interior working of the machinery must be foul. There is as much mining and countermining for power, as many fluctuations of friendship and enmity, as many attractions and repulsions, bargains and oppositions, narrated in these memories as might be told of our own times. Walpole witnessed it all as a sharer in the sport, and now tells it to the world as a Satirist— And shall not I too, have a tale to tell?

10. VI— Heard Mr Little—in the morning from 2. Chronicles 19.11. last clause of the verse “Deal courageously, and the Lord shall be with the good.” He gave a historical account of the reformation effected by Jehoshaphat in the Kingdom of Judah by Jehoshapat; and made his application by a comment upon the necessity of dealing courageously to accomplish any reformation whether religious or political; and upon the cheering pledge in the text, that the Lord shall be with the good— There was no Lecture after the Morning Service, but an annual meeting of the Trustees of the Society, for Elections— Mr Bailey called on me between the Services— The afternoon Sermon was from 1. Corinthians 15.34 “Awake to righteousness, and sin not; for some have not the knowledge of God: I speak this to your shame”— This is the same Chapter from which Mr Little had taken his text for the funeral sermon upon the Death of Mr John Law. He spoke of it this day as one of the most beautiful Chapters in the Bible— It is among the most sublime—and the most awful— The family attended the Evening at Mr Lowrie’s Church, and heard a Mr Neal from Philadelphia, with whom they were well pleased. I remained at home, writing to redeem the arrears of this Diary, brought the month of October to a close.

11. VI:Mr Charles Pinkney, Secretary of the Legation at St. Petersburg, came this morning to my house and delivered Despatches from Mr Middleton, which he brings as special messenger. The most important one was the Convention to carry into effect the Emperor Alexander’s decision, upon the Slave question of the Treaty of Ghent. Pinkney left St. Petersburg the 28th. of July, and sailed from Cronstadt the next day. I had already received despatches from Mr Middleton, nearly a Month later in date, and began to be much concerned and apprehensive for Pinkney. He arrived last week at Newport, Rhode-Island, and comes here after stopping a day or two with his mother and family at Baltimore. His long passage was occasioned by the vessel’s running ashore on the Island of Gothland, where they were detained 22 days— Mr Bailey brought me a despatch received this morning from J. Forsyth at Madrid with various enclosures. At one O’Clock, Pinkney called at the Office— I went with him to the President’s and introduced him. On returning from the President’s I was occupied, until sent for home to dinner in reading the despatches from Mr Middleton, and Mr Forsyth. The papers with the Treaty are not numerous; but there are other communications highly confidential, particularly a Letter of
Instructions from the late Lord Castlereagh, to Sir Charles Bagot written at Hanover in October 1821. fully disclosing the policy of the British Cabinet, and of the European Alliance, with reference to the differences between Russia and Turkey. Mr Forsyth’s despatch gives as usual a list of a new Ministry in Spain, and represents the political State of that Country as more disturbed and threatening than at any former period, since their last Revolution— A Coll. San Miguel is now the Minister of foreign Affairs.— I received a Note from the new Portuguese Chargé d’Affaires, Constancio, requesting an interview with me, which I appointed for to-morrow at two O’Clock. — There was a Note from Baron Stackelberg, to Mr D. Brent, complaining of another visit at his house from the Constable Waters. I desired Mr Brent to see the Mayor of the City again, and request him to give warning to all the Police Officers of the City, of the penalties to which they will expose themselves, if they presume to enter the house of a foreign Minister, or to serve a process upon any person of his family— I gave him also to shew to the Mayor, the written statement of Stackelberg’s valet de chambre, Bede— This Evening Mrs. Adams and the family went and heard a Mr M’Ginnis preach at Mr Lowrie’s Church. I was at home, writing in this Diary. The Secretary of the Navy, Mr Smith Thompson, returned this day to the City, with his family, after an absence of four Months.

12. VI:Mr Virgil H. Barber, of the Roman Catholic Seminary here, going to be Pastor of a Church at Claremont New-Hampshire, called for a Letter of Introduction to my father, which I had promised him and now gave him— I paid a visit to Captain Angus, at Mrs Wilson’s— I had not seen him since August 1814. at Ghent. At two Mr Francisco Solano Constancio, the new Chargé d’Affaires from Portugal, came to the Office. He is new in the Diplomatic Career, to which he has been introduced by the late Revolution in Portugal. He comes last from France, and appears lively and loquacious— He told me that his introductory Letter to me from the Portuguese Minister of foreign Affairs was of an old date. That he had read the latest Correspondence between me and Mr Amado-Grehon—that he should not revive the subjects of it, without further Instructions from his Government— That they had naturally been much pressed by Claimants, Portuguese and Brazilian, who had suffered by capture of their property; but he was happy that nothing further of that kind was likely to occur. Portugal was now at Peace with all the world, and there was not even a flag of Artigas, under which captures of Portuguese property could be made— Portugal was disposed to recognize the Independence of all South-America, not excepting Brazil itself, if the People there should desire it. He professed also great attachment to the United States, and high admiration of our political Institutions; and said he had been several times on the point of coming to settle in this Country as a private individual— He wished to be presented to the President, for which with the President’s subsequent approbation I appointed one O’Clock, to-morrow. I received despatches from J. M. Forbes at Buenos-Ayres, and from Condy Raguet our new Consul, at Rio de Janeiro, and from his predecessor there, the vice-Consul Sartoris. All revolutionary and convulsive. In Brazil, proclaiming Independence, under the auspices of the Prince. At Buenos-Ayres struggling faction against faction, and fanaticism against freedom, without any settlement, and with little prospect of any settlement upon principles of order, justice, or liberty. I took all these despatches, and those yesterday received from Russia, and from Spain to the President, with whom I left them— The President read to me the paragraphs prepared for his Message relating to Great-Britain and the Colonial intercourse, to France and the Commercial Convention, and to Russia and the mediated Convention—also those concerning South-America, and the illegal blockades of both parties to that War. He had not prepared the paragraphs concerning the state of the Treasury, but told me that although since his return Mr Crawford had sent him a statement less favourable than those he had before received from the Chief Clerk and Register of the Treasury, the receipts of the year would exceed the estimate by more than four Millions of dollars— I mentioned to the President the Negotiation for which we must be prepared with the Russian Minister daily expected, Baron Tuyl, concerning the Russian claims on the North-west Coast of this Continent, and which I apprehend will be of considerable
difficulty, for the whole claim on the part of Russia seems to be groundless. The Emperor has committed himself on the face of the world to pretensions that he cannot sustain, and now comes to obtain by negotiation, a part of the wrong by renouncing the remainder— The President said he had no doubt the Emperor would be satisfied with Latitude 55 for the boundary; but I remarked that we had no immediate interest in the boundary question. Having no claim of our own, North of 49. it was immaterial to us whether Russia came to 55 or to 51— That was a question particularly for Great-Britain— He said the maritime question might be settled by reducing the claim of exclusive jurisdiction to a distance of one marine league from the Shore— I did not apprehend any difficulty in that— The prohibition to our Citizens of trading with the Indians of the North-west Coast, was the knot that I expected, and the embarrassment will be, that having no counter-claim on our part, whatever we agree to in the negotiation must in its nature be concessions without equivalent— I desired the President to turn his attention to this subject; and to consider, whether it would be expedient to communicate with the British Government through Mr Canning or Mr Rush concerning it— He said Great-Britain might treat such a communication, as she had done with the proposal for acknowledging the Independence of Buenos-Aires— Communicate it immediately to Russia, and turn it to her own account— To avoid this, I asked if it might not upon the first overtures from Baron Tuyl, meet them immediately by an enquiry how the question stands in this affair, between Great Britain and Russia; with a frank avowal that we think Great-Britain has so much claim of interest in this concern, that no effective arrangement of it can be concluded without consulting her— He said it would deserve great consideration— I also spoke of the necessity of settling some determinate system of diplomatic intercourse with the South-American Governments, and expressed my opinion that of the five Plenipotentiary Missions, for which appropriations were made at the last Session of Congress, one at the most, ought to be now filled, and I had doubts even of that— If they should however be filled, I hoped C. Pinkney would be appointed as one of the Secretaries; as I supposed he would not wish to return to Russia— The President will consult the Cabinet, on the whole subject— Mr Petry, French Consul General, and young Laborie, attached to the Legation spent the Evening with us, and I took a hand at whist.

13. VI.Dr Thornton came in the Morning to tell me that he had sent to make enquiries of Dr Huntt, and was informed that Mrs Middleton, wife of young Arthur Middleton, and daughter of General Van Ness, was this morning a little better— Her life has been despaired of these two days; and her situation has excited great interest in the City— The Dr spoke also of certain repairs that he wishes to have made at the Patent Office— Visit from Captain Hull; who has just gone through the ordeal of a Court of Enquiry into his conduct, as Commander of the Navy-Yard at Charlestown— A violent and almost universal prejudice had been excited against him, and this Court of Enquiry which sat sixty days upon him, was one of the severest tests thro’ which it was possible for an Officer to pass— The Report has not yet been published, but goes to his full justification. He is yet under great excitement, at the persecution that he has experienced— He told me that Captain Evans, had been treated in the same manner at New-York, and three days since attempted to commit suicide— At one O’Clock I accompanied the Portuguese Charge d’Affaires, and Mr Schmitz whom he introduced as attached to the Legation, to the President’s, and presented them to him— He received them in the small drawing-room, without formality— Mr Constancio repeated to him, the substance of what he had said yesterday to me, and reciprocal professions of friendly dispositions between the two Countries, and Governments were passed as usual in such cases. Mr Constancio particularly dwelt upon the similarity of principles on which the two Governments were now founded, since the late
regeneration of Portugal, as forming new links of attachment between them— After they had withdrawn I had some conversation with the President, concerning the despatches from Russia and from Spain which I had left with him yesterday. He had not yet read them through— There was a Letter too from Jeremy Robinson, at St Iago de Chili to which I had called the President’s special attention— It is dated 25 May last, and is filled with bitter complaints against all the naval Officers of the United States who have commanded in the Pacific since 1817. and against J. B. Prevost the Agent, whose conduct appears not to have been exactly what it ought to have been, but against whom nothing definite has been proved which required, or would justify a direct censure upon him. From the President, I went to the Office of the Navy Department, and saw the Secretary Mr Thompson— He agreed that immediate payment should be made at Boston of Mr Cruft’s bill— We had some general conversation upon the issue of the recent Elections in the State of New-York, which introduce the new organization of their State Constitution— I renewed my application in behalf of three young men, who solicit warrants as Midshipmen: Whitcomb, Bradlee, and Amory; to whose claims he promised to give attention, when the appointments should be made— At my Office, Mr Calhoun called to recommend a Mr Simmons now residing at St. Augustine, as a member of the Legislative Council of Florida. I renewed a despatch with several enclosures, dated 9. September from J. Forsyth at Madrid— Increasing troubles in Spain. George dined at Mr T. Munroe’s. Commodore Patterson was here this Evening, but I did not see him— Chess with W. S. Smith.

14. VI:Force called this Morning—To bind a blank book for Diary minutes—He has been so careless, about the distribution of my pamphlet, that where it was in demand, it was not to be had. I received a Letter concerning it yesterday from Hopkinson at Philadelphia— He approves my argument on the effect of War upon Treaties, and on our Right to the Fisheries. I left Cards at Strother’s for Mr. Constancio, and Mr Schmitz. Mr Anderson the Comptroller came to the Office, and introduced to me, Mr M’Lean, the new Commissioner of the Land-Office, who within a few days has arrived and entered upon the Execution of its duties— Anderson was inquisitive about the Convention just brought by C. Pinkney, and shewed some disposition to criticize its provisions— That Convention too might pass through its ordeal— I took up my draft to Anduaga, upon the Case of Escandell, and the charge against the late Captain Elton of having concealed his papers— But I had not all the documents necessary to proceed with it— We had company to dine— Captain Angus, Mr Constancio, Mr Cox, Commodore Hull, Mr R. I. Johnston, Commodores Patterson, Porter, Rodgers and Tingey and Mrs Tingey, Mr Charles Pinkney, Mr Schmitz and Mr and Mrs Wingate— 20 at Table— There had also been invited Commodore and Mrs Chauncey, Coll. Henderson, Lieutenant Levy, Mrs Porter, Mrs Rodgers, and Mrs Wheeler— After the rest of the company went away, Pinkney remained, and entertained us with Music— He sings in French, German, Italian, Russian and English with equal facility, and with self-accompaniment on the Piano. He has turned his time and opportunities to excellent account at least for the acquisition of ornamental accomplishments— Chess with W. S. Smith.

15. VI:30.Mr Daniel Brent andWalsh came to my house on the subject of a capture made by a Spanish Privateer from St. Iago de Cuba, of a Schooner from Baltimore, called the Harriet Captain Baker— She was taken returning from Carthagena, and plundered of the valuable part of her Cargo, and especially of 8 or 10 000 dollars in doubloons— There are several claims of an Insurance Company in Baltimore, but Walsh is the Agent for George Woodbine a British Subject (I suppose the some time noted associate of Arbuthnott, of Seminole War Memory) to whom 6000 dollars of the doubloons belonged— The British Admiral on the Station was applied to for interference to recover the property, but declined, because taken in an American vessel— Mr Walsh asks an order to the Commander of one of our Cruizers to go to St. Iago de Cuba, with the vouchers and demand restitution of the property, which he supposes to be now attainable— The owners of the privateer being known and solvent. Her Commission has already been taken from her— I promised to apply to the Secretary
of the Navy for the requested order. At the Office, Mr Seaton came to ask a further advance of 1000 dollars upon the digest of manufactures to be printed for Congress— 3500 dollars have already been advanced, and Seaton urged that the cost of printing the whole would amount to at least 12000 dollars. I asked him if he would pledge himself to have the work ready to be laid on the tables of the members the first day of the Session— He could not promise— They have been disappointed of their supply of Paper from Patterson, and are expecting a Supply from Baltimore, hourly— I told Seaton that they must postpone their necessities for money, till they got their paper— That the members of Congress would be much dissatisfied if this document should not be ready for them at the commencement of the Session, and that I had finally dismissed Colvin from the Department principally for his neglect of this work. Seaton said I ought to have dismissed Colvin two years ago: but at last he said that if he could not raise 800 dollars by this day at 3. O’Clock, his partner Gales must go to Jail: and that this was the real cause of this application to me. I directed the advance to be made. Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy came to my office— I spoke to him of the Spanish Minister’s charge against the late Captain Elton, upon Escandell’s complaint, and desired him to have enquiry made of the Officers of the Spark, who were with Elton at the time of the capture of the Neptune, concerning the facts, which he promised— Some months since I received a Letter from Richard Emmons, in Kentucky, enclosing the 30th. Canto of an Epic Poem in 36. Books, of which the author requested my opinion as a critic. The subject of the Poem, was the late War with Great-Britain; and the 30th. Canto, was called the Cruize of the immortal Blakely— A critical opinion upon an Epic Poem in thirty six Books, was a serious and delicate affair. How could it be given with candour? how could it be declined with civility? To have answered with commendation and persifflage would have been easy, but inhuman, and unworthy of the gravity of my Station— I left the Poem, and the Poet’s Letter in one of the drawers of my table, till I received a few days since a second Letter from the author, much concerned at having received no answer from me, and apprehensive that his Cruize of the immortal Blakely was lost. I answered his Letters this day, and enclosed his thirtieth Canto, declining to give an opinion upon his Epic Poem, and commending his Patriotism— I took up the draft of answer to the Spanish Minister on the case of Escandell, but could not finish it for want of documents. Mr Charles Pinkney dined and spent the Evening with us; beat me at Chess; then played a losing game; and finished by amusing the Ladies with Music.

16. VII.Doctor Richard Weightman from Saint Augustine, brought to the Office an Account to be settled of a Judge Bethune, who has acted as a territorial judge in East-Florida— I called at the President’s with the despatch last received from J. Forsyth, and its enclosures— The Secretary of the Navy came in, while I was there, to enquire concerning the account of J. H. Morel the Marshal in Georgia. The President directed that it should not be paid, and strongly inclined to the opinion that Morel ought to be dismissed from Office— The President read to me, the paragraphs relating to foreign Affairs which he has drawn up for the message—particularly those relating to Spain and Portugal, to South-America, to Russia, Turkey, and the Greeks and to the unsettled State of Europe— I doubted most of those concerning Spain and Portugal, in which he had spoken of their revolutionary Prospects, more favourably than I thought the state of facts according to our most recent information would warrant— He said he would revise them; and would attend particularly to the last despatch from Mr Forsyth— His paragraph concerning the Greeks, with a strong expression of sympathy in their favour, adds a sentiment equally explicit that neither Justice nor policy would justify on our part any active interference in their cause. The President said he hoped to be ready to bring the draft of the whole message before a Meeting
of the members of the Administration next Tuesday— He proposes also to say something of the repairs of the Cumberland Road; being satisfied that Congress have the right of appropriating money to that purpose— He told me there was another subject that gave him great uneasiness— It was the condition of Richard Cutts, second Comptroller, and of William Lee, second Auditor of the Treasury— He had heard for the first time, this day, Circumstances related of the individual conduct of Mr Cutts, which he thought it impossible for him to pass over without notice. Yet what would become of him, if he should be dismissed from Office? I said I had heard much of them both; as their situation was of great notoriety— But I knew nothing of either, which would require his removal from Office— He said he would hear their explanations— Evening at home reading the Newspapers and Walpole’s Memoires.

17. VI:30. The Services at the Unitarian Church were performed by Mr Taylor of Philadelphia; whose Morning Sermon was from John 13.19. “Now I tell you before it come, that, when it is come to pass ye may believe that I am he.” The general subject was the effect of prophecy as Evidence of the truth of Christianity. He divided the prophecies concerning Christ into two Classes: those contained in the Books of the Old-Testament, and those given out by himself in the New— And subdivided again the latter, into prophesies accomplished while he lived, and those fulfilled since his decease. Among the prophecies of the old Testament, he spoke with special emphasis of those of Isaiah, so clear, so precise, so circumstantial that it seemed as if they could only have been written after the Event; insomuch that this prophet had sometimes been denominated the fifth Evangelist; though his prophecies had been delivered 700 years before the birth of Christ— Of the prophecies of Jesus himself fulfilled while he lived he remarked the minuteness of the incidents equally beyond the reach of human foresight and deception—such as the piece of money found in the mouth of the fish—the colt tied in the village for which he sent—the man with a pitcher who was to be followed into the house where he meant to keep the passover, and the furnished upper chamber into which they would be shewn— The designation of the disciple who would betray him— The declaration to the disciples themselves that they would all desert him, and the positive prediction of his own death— Of those fulfilled since his decease, the declaration concerning the woman who anointed his feet, and the prediction of the destruction of Jerusalem were chiefly particularized as Events exceedingly improbable when foretold, yet so exactly realized that it was impossible to compare the narrative of the destruction of Jerusalem in Josephus, with the prediction, without astonishment— The text of the afternoon discourse was 1. Corinthians 10.32. “Give none Offense, neither to the Jews, nor to the Gentiles, nor to the church of God”— After explaining the meaning of the text necessarily to be an injunction to give no one, just Cause of Offence, he enlarged first upon the general Christian duty of kindness, benevolence, and brotherly love, as applicable to all mankind, and then, following the division suggested by the words of the text pointed out the line of conduct suitable for the members of this Society, towards those of other Christian denominations, towards unbelievers, and towards those of the Society itself. With regard to all, he inculcated the Laws of Charity and Love— With both these sermons I was much gratified, and ought to be improved; by the first in confirmation of faith; by the second in purity of heart, and kindliness of affection towards my fellow men: It is hard in the observation and reflection of a long human life, to preserve in untainted certainty the belief—either of Christianity, or of a life beyond the grave. It is yet harder in the conflicts with the world, and with human depravity to retain the feeling of brotherly kindness towards all men— Whatever tends
to confirm confidence in the truth of the gospel, and to fortify the social affections is profitable to direct; and points to the path of virtue. Evening employed on this Diary.

18. VI: Arrears of the present season redeemed. Baron Stackelberg being the Swedish Charge d’Affaires, called at the Office, to say he has received the Exequatur for a Swedish Consul at Norfolk, and also that Mr Brent had given him satisfactory explanations with regard to the second visit of the Constable Waters to his house. He gave me notice likewise, though he said not officially, that Mr Lorich the Swedish Consul General had left Philadelphia for some months— He believed gone to the Colony. St. Bartholomew’s. I received Letters from J. B. Prevost at St. Iago de Chili to 24. July last and one from Jeremy Robinson at St Valparaiso of 5. August— A new organization of the Government there had just been effected, of which Prevost speaks with high approbation, and Robinson with equal severity. I also received a Letter with returns of vessels arrived at the Sandwich Islands, from Mr Jones, the Consular Agent there. I took up the Resolution of the House of Representatives of 16. April last, calling upon each of the Heads of Departments for a report, on the first day of the next Session, of the number of Officers and Messengers retained in their respective Departments, and if any, how many of them are unnecessary, inefficient, or engaged in other pursuits or professions, in no wise relating to the public service— In preparing to report upon this last point, I found it advisable to ask the question directly of the Clerks in the Department themselves, and drew up a direction to that effect; requiring of each of them a statement in writing, and subscribed— Mrs. Adams, with Mary Hellen and George went to the Theatre, which is opened for this week only, being the week of the Races, and of the great Race for 20000 dollars between the Virginia horse, Sir Charles, and the New-York horse Eclipse— I passed the Evening at home, and began a Letter to Joseph Hopkinson— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith left us, having taken lodgings at Mr Wheaton’s.

19 VI:15.G. S. Bulfinch called this morning at my house with Mr Taylor of Philadelphia, the preacher of last Sunday. At the Office, Commodore Chauncey came with a claim of 1000 dollars for having acted as Commissioner with W. Shaler in negotiating the last Algerine Treaty. He had spoken to me of this sometime before; and refers to the Precedents of Commodore Decatur and Bainbridge who have received like compensation for similar services. Mr Charles Minifies came with a long Letter, setting forth his want of an Office— He said he had been this Morning to the President, who had referred him to the Secretary of State— He left his Letter; and is to come again, about next Monday. A Mr Levy a resident of Saint Augustine, came to make representations concerning the negroes captured in the Spanish Ship General Ramirez, now in the custody of the Marshal of Georgia, Morel— The General Ramirez was a Spanish Slave ship from the Havana—captured with a Cargo of near 300 slaves, by a South-American privateer; recaptured by one of our Cruizers, brought in and libelled as a prize from a Pirate— The court adjudged that the Privateer was not a Pirate, and decreed restitution of the Vessel and Cargo to the South-American Captors— This decision of the District Court in Georgia, was appealed from by the U.S. District Attorney, confirmed by the Circuit Court: again appealed from to the Supreme Court, before whom it was brought last February, and continued over to the next Term. Mr Levy comes in behalf of the owner of the Negroes, as he says an inhabitant of the Havana— He complains of great hardship in the case. The importation of Slaves being now prohibited at the Havana, so that the owner cannot send them there even if they should be restored to him. Levy wishes therefore an Executive order authorising him to take them into Florida, upon condition that after a service of ten years they shall be emancipated. I called at the President’s to take his directions in this case, but he was at dinner. I did not see him— Johnson Hellen came in the Evening from Rockville.
Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen spent the Evening with Mrs Smith. George at the Theatre. I read the Newspapers, and wrote to Joseph Hopkinson. I had lost the Morning in assorting papers; Letters of the year 1821.

20. VI:30.Mrs Davis and another Lady came with a subscription Book, for a Baptist Meeting-house at the Navy-Yard— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, where I met General Van Ness— He told me that his daughter Mrs Middleton was this day worse— I went with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George to see the Race, between the New-York Horse American Eclipse, and the Virginia Horse Sir Charles. Mr Harrison the owner of the latter some weeks since challenged Mr Van Ranst owner of Eclipse, to this Race for a rubber of four mile heats, upon a stake of ten thousand dollars on each side— The challenge was accepted, and 5000 dollars on each part were deposited in the branch Bank to be forfeited on failure to run— Both horses have been here upwards of a week; and expectation of the race has been excited by newspaper paragraphs, throughout the Union— There were probably ten thousand persons upon the course— But Sir Charles met with some accident last week, in one of his knee joints, and although his lameness was not unequivocally perceptible, yet his owner finally concluded to pay the forfeit rather than let him run— Afterwards however he agreed to a new match to run one four mile heat for 1000 dollars— But the Virginia horse was ridden by a black-boy and the New-Yorker by a white man— The white man gained an advantage at the start, which the blacky never recovered— They ran the first mile in one minute fifty-five seconds, with equal speed; the second in two minutes four seconds, Eclipse gaining five or six feet— The third in 2 minutes 2 Seconds; Eclipse gaining at least 30 feet, and he ran the fourth round in 2 minutes 3 seconds, Sir Charles having failed in midway; thoroughly lamed, and scarcely able to limp off the course— Johnson Hellen returned from the field directly to Rockville— At the Office Mr Levy came again, about the negroes from the General Ramirez, but I had not seen the President. I began the draft of a Report to the House of Representatives upon their Resolution of 7. May last respecting the Clerks in the Executive Departments— Mr and Mrs Smith and Mr Petry, were here this Evening. I was writing to Mr Hopkinson— Received a Reply from Mr Canning on the Colonial Intercourse Regulations.

21. VI:30. Rain for the annual-races. Mr John Marshall junr. son of the Chief Justice of the United States, came to recommend a friend of his Henry Dixon for appointment as an Officer in the Marine Corps— I went with him to the Navy Department, and introduced him to Mr Thompson the Secretary. The Bishop of Louisiana, Dubourg came in behalf of a Convent of Ursuline Nuns at New-Orleans, disquieted, as to their title to the Land upon which their buildings stand— In April 1818 an Act of Congress authorized the President to sell adjoining Lands which had formerly belonged to the Convent, but many years before the Cession to the United States had been taken for Barracks and a military Hospital— Shortly after the passage of the Act of Congress the Nuns sent a memorial to the President, protesting against the Sale, which they rather gratuitously seem to apprehend was meant to include their own land and buildings; but advancing a claim to the Barrack and Hospital Lands also, on the plea, that they had been originally granted to them but were afterwards taken by Louis 15. for the special purpose of a military hospital and barracks— The Nuns say that if the lands are to be appropriated to other purposes, they ought in justice and Equity to revert to them. The President took the opinion of the Attorney-General upon the Memorial, which was that the Nuns were entitled to their own premises and ought not to be disturbed in them: but that their claim to the Barrack and Hospital Land, could not be allowed by the Executive— The Bishop who has come here from St. Louis, Missouri, on this affair did not know that the Nuns had ever advanced this latter claim, which he said was a folly; and was otherwise misinformed concerning the state of the business— He had understood that at two several times in the last four years, Letters in behalf of the Nuns had been written to me, and remained unanswered— No Letter to me of that sort had
ever been received; the Memorial had been transmitted to the President directly: he had taken the opinion of the Attorney-General upon it; and then deposited the papers at the Department of State— The Bishop said his only object was that the claim of the United States to that portion of the Estate, in which the opinion of the Attorney-General, pronounced the title of the Nuns to be good should be removed— But as the subject matter is the resort of the General Land-Office, which is an appendage to the Treasury Department, I referred him to the Treasury, and directed the papers to be sent to Mr Crawford— I took to the President, the Note received last Evening from Mr Canning, and a Letter of 1. October, from C Raguet, Consul at Rio de Janeiro, where a Declaration of Independence has already issued, and where preparations were making for proclaiming the Prince, on the 12th. of October, Emperor of Brasil— As the latest accounts from Lisbon announce the adoption of measures by the Cortes there, which forebode a conflict between Portugal and Brazil, I observed to the President that we should be very soon called to assume a distinct attitude in relation to that question— He said he would notice it in the Message— Also the Affairs of Florida— W. P. Duval, the Governor of that Territory, has taken leave to absent himself from it for several months, which has given dissatisfaction there, and which the President disapproves. He directed me to write to Duval, that it was expected that he would immediately return— The President gave me to read, Letters to him from Jeremy Robinson at Valparaiso of 5. August with the speech of the Director O’Higgins on the new organization of the Government of Chili—from the Marquis de Marbois of 18. August— He proposes to write a History of the Cession of Louisiana, and writes to ask for a communication of any documents, or printed works relating to it which have been published here— He says it has become a sort of fashion to blame the Cession of Louisiana (meaning in France) a circumstance not surprising, but indicative of the restless ambition yet burning in the bosoms of French Statesmen— And from General John D’Evereux, Commander of the Irish Legion in the Army of the Colombian Republic. This Letter is dated Bogota, 22 September last, and its object is to persuade the President to issue Letters of Marque and reprizal against Spain, to prevent the Colombian Republicans from falling into Monarchy; to which he intimates they are dangerously addicted— Mr Levy called again at the Office— I told him that the President had as I expected, said he had no authority to bargain either for ten years of servitude, or for the subsequent emancipation of the Ramirez Negroes— Nor for their transportation to Florida— That for the peculiarity of the case, Congress only could provide— He asked, if the President would recommend the subject to Congress?— I said it would be better for the parties concerned to apply by Petition or Memorial— The President had also told me that Levy had made a direct application to him on another subject. That he had a sugar plantation in East-Florida, whence he wanted to make a road to St. Augustine— And the President thinks that is the purpose for which he wants the Ramirez Negroes— I commenced a view of the Duties assigned by various Acts of Congress to the Department of State— George dined at Baron Stackelberg’s; and in the Evening with C. Pinkney attended Mrs. Adams and Mary Hellen to Carrusi’s Race-Ball.

22. VI:30. Rain all day. Called at Strother’s and left a Card for J. Marshall junr.R. Derby was gone. At the Office, I wrote to W. P. Duvall, Governor of Florida, requiring him to return thither, and to A. H. Everett, giving him leave of absence for six Months from the 1st. of next May— Resumed the view of the duties assigned to the Department of State, in which I made however but little progress— Mr Bailey shewed me a Letter from General H. A. S. Dearborn, to Mr Joseph Wingate now here— Passed the Evening in reading Newspapers, and writing to my son John.

23. VII: A young man called on me this morning, who said his name was Charles J. F. Alden. That he was a Son of the President of Alleghany College, in Pennsylvania, 22 years old— That in September of last year, he went to the West Indies for the recovery of his health: had spent the Winter at the Havana, and had since been at Jamaica, whence he was upon his return to this country robbed by Pirates, off Cape Saint Antonio, of all his Clothes and Money: afterwards landed at Newbern in North-Carolina, whence he had made his way this far on foot, and now wanted the means to proceed home to his father’s house. His appearance corresponded so exactly with his story, that I did not hesitate to lend him as much money as he desired to carry him home— Went with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George to the last day’s Races, for the Season— Lady Lightfoot a Mare 11 years old, took a purse of 500 dollars, in two four mile heats beating the Colt Tyro, 3 years old— This Race was well run; not more than 8 minutes 10 Seconds to a heat, and both won by not more than the horse’s length. There was then made a purse of 200 dollars for five, one mile heats, 15 minutes interval between the heats— The first horse in three of the five heats to take the purse— Six horses were entered, four of which were withdrawn by the fourth round— William Tayloe’s horse Quaker, took the purse— I met Mr Frye, with Robert Buchanan on the Course; and Mr Jeremiah Nelson member of Congress from Massachusetts, who arrived last Evening— The course was very thinly attended in comparison with Wednesday— The course is circular and I walked round it in 16 minutes and a half whence I ascertained that it was a good measured Mile— It was near five O’Clock when we returned home— I stopped at the Office, and found there a heavy Mail of Letters and despatches— The Six Brothers from Havre has arrived; but without either The Russian Minister, the Baron de Tuyll, or Hersant of the French Legation; both of whom were expected in her. Tuyll embarked in her, but was taken ill, and landed at Kinsals in Ireland. I received despatches from A. Gallatin to 26. September— Endorsed as sent by his son James. I received also a complimentary Letter from the Baron Hyde de Neuville—an anonymous one of six Sheets from Buenos-Ayres 4. August—an inquisitive letter from the Secretary of the Treasury: one with curious enclosures about Lehuby’s Colony, from Isaac Cox Barnet the Consul at Paris, and many others— It was past six when I got home to dinner.— Dr and Mrs Thornton, Mrs W. S. Smith, Messrs.Pinkney, Cox, Parish, and Laborie spent the Evening with us— Chess with Dr Thornton— Mrs Middleton, General Van Ness’s daughter, died this day, in the 19th. year of her age.

24. VI: Heard this morning Mr Taylor at the Unitarian Church, from Luke 16.2. “Give an account of thy stewardship.”— There was a suitable solemnity in his treatment of the subject which is itself solemn. He dwelt with earnestness on the topic of future retribution, and disclaimed as no genuine principle of unitarians that there can be any merit towards God, in good works. This discourse was less impressive and more in the beaten track than either of those delivered by Mr Taylor last Sunday— At one O’Clock we attended the funeral of Mrs Middleton; who was buried in a grave-yard of the family, near the Catholic Church— The attendance was numerous, and the sympathy with the distress of the family very general.— An only child, married less than a year ago, with every prospect of a long and happy life, thus prematurely cut off in the prime gives a lesson upon the delusions of earthly hope, which appeals for the moment to every heart— There was on account of this funeral, no afternoon service at the Unitarian Church. We attended at the second presbyterian, and heard Mr Campbell; from 2. Timothy 4.7. “I have finished my course.” After various oratorical illustrations, of the exultation, natural to persons engaged in laborious, painful and perilous projects upon the successful conclusion of their career, and a panegyric upon Saint Paul as one of the most distinguished and effective Apostles of Christ; he divided his subject into the consideration of the beginning the progress and the termination of the Christian’s course— It must begin with regeneration. This brought the preacher at once into the train of calvinistic doctrines, which thenceforth guided him to his conclusion. How is it, that men will pertinaciously insist upon being told as Mr Campbell told his hearers, that
every one of them knew his own heart to be deceitful above all things and desperately wicked; and yet that they would resist as a cruel injury the slightest allusion to any specific imputation of wrong to any of them individually? Is it that all the terrors of Calvinism are dealt out in indefinite and vague generalities? That even a conscious sentiment of desperate wickedness without reference to particular criminality, is one of the modes of self-flattery and pride?— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us, and Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mr John Payne Todd passed the Evening here— Among the Letters received by the Mail this day was one from Madame Bourke, and one from the Chevalier Brancia, both written at Paris, and recommending a Mr Lucchese, who came out in the Six Brothers and is going to Mexico. He sends these Letters from Philadelphia, where he is sick and asks of me Letters of recommendation to Mexico— Mr Crawford told me this day that he had received Letters from Mr Gallatin and Mr Forsyth— Gallatin he says will certainly come home in the Spring— And Forsyth writes that he shall take leave at Madrid, before the 4th. of March. He is elected a member of the House of Representatives in Congress, for Georgia—for the 18th. Congress.

25. VI:30. A Mr M’Closkey came this Morning for a certificate from the Department of State to authenticate a paper— Then a Mr M’Gowan with a recommendation from several members of Congress, to solicit a Clerkship in forma pauperis— He referred for his qualifications to the digest of the manufacturing returns upon which he has been employed— Having had those of the State of Ohio assigned to him upon which he said he had worked Night and day. At the Office Mr Bates the Delegate from the territory of Arkansas brought a Printer’s bill for printing the Laws of the last Session, and enquired concerning the re-appointment of R. Crittenden the Secretary, and Scott one of the judges of the territory— It appeared that the Governor, Miller’s Commission, which expired the 3d. of March last, had not been renewed—much to my surprize— Charles Minifie, came again to ask for employment; as there is no vacancy in the Department he took back his memorial to the President; setting forth his wants and his claims. Mr George Hay came to take leave; going upon a visit to Richmond— The Legislature of the State are to meet there next week; and his journey there just at this time has perhaps some other motive than that which he assigned to me, of settling a long standing account with his overseer. He gave me his opinion of Mr Sheffey, heretofore a federal member of Congress of some distinction, and who he told me would be this year in the Virginia Legislature. Mr Canning came with a note upon the old subject of discrimination between rolled and hammered iron, in our Tariff, the Consideration of which was postponed from the last Session of Congress— But we had a long and desultory Conversation upon various topics, chiefly however upon the Colonial Intercourse— We went over again all the topics which have been discussed between us before, both in Conversation and in Correspondence, on this subject: he intimated to me that many of our own Merchants, thought we had not met the regulations of the Act of Parliament, opening the Colonial Ports, with equal reciprocity— I said I had no doubt he had been and would be told so.— But he must be aware that most or all of the Merchants in this Country with whom he was acquainted or in correspondence are either British Subjects or so connected, as to be in British Interests— Our merchants told a very different story— There would be doubtless a bias of partiality on both sides, but our Merchants would of course expect that we should attend to their Interests— He said he thought Congress would see the thing in a more favourable light than this; I replied that if such a disposition should be manifested in Congress, it would in no wise be counteracted by the Executive, whose only object is to secure the interests of our own People, consistently with the most entire and liberal reciprocity— He said all the British Merchants, here, were confident that with
the existing tonnage and discriminating duties, in six weeks more there could not be a single British vessel in the trade— I read to him a paragraph from a Letter of Jehu Hollingsworth, dated the 20th. of October at St. Eustatius, and declaring that all of the American vessels that have entered at St. Kitts, and Nevis since the opening of the Ports, not one had been satisfied— He touched again upon the discrimination made by us between the North-American, and the West-Indian British Colonies, which I defended and he contested on the same arguments as heretofore— I told him it was probable however that Congress might remove that discrimination and substitute other regulations in its stead. Perhaps a limitation to direct voyages, both to and from the Colonies— Perhaps a limited list of imports, excepting the most important of their export articles; such as Rum, for which they could find no other market, as they excluded our salted fish, and provisions— He said he was sure that was what I was coming to—and again intimated the threat of closing the Ports again, which I again told him they were quite free to do: and would no doubt do, if they found it for their interest. We knew that had been their motive for opening the Ports— He said we supposed they had been compelled by our restrictive measures to open the Ports; but he believed we were in that mistaken— I said that we did not attribute it altogether to that— We ascribed much to the Independence of the South American Provinces under which it was impossible that the old exclusive and excluding Colonial system should much longer endure, any where. He remarked that the reason upon which Colonies were confined to exclusive intercourse, with the mother Country was the expense, of their Settlement— Observing me to smile at this, he asked whether it was not so?— I asked how much expense, the Settlement of Mexico and Peru had cost Spain under Cortes and Pizarro? I added it was conquest and conversion: the Bull of Alexander 6. and the sword of injustice, in which the exclusions of modern Colonization had originated. Spain had set the example— She had forbidden foreigners from setting a foot in her Colonies, upon pain of death and the other Colonizing States of Europe, had imitated the exclusion, though not the rigour of the penalty— The expense of colonizing had formed no part of the Consideration— The whole system of modern Colonization was an abuse of Government, and it was time that it should come to an end. But he said that the British Colonies had been settled upon principles of the utmost liberality. I asked him if he had ever read Neal’s History of the Puritans?— No— Well— He knew that the first Settlement of New-England was made by Puritans— Yes— And they were outcasts from their Country, for the sake of Conscience; and Pilgrims from Holland to a Wilderness in America for the sake of their Country— They came here to escape turning to Dutchmen, and even here could not obtain a Charter securing to them the blessing of toleration— He said that was because intolerance was unfortunately the Spirit of that age; which I admitted, but thought it no proof of the liberality of the British System— Mr Canning was also very inquisitive about this expedition of General Ducoudray Holstein and Baptis Irvine against the Island of Porto-Rico, which he seemed to fear was not yet entirely broken up— He betrayed more of alarm than he avowed— It was apparent to me that he suspected the expedition had been secretly sanctioned or connived at by the American Government and that we, intended to make ourselves Masters of Porto-Rico— Without appearing to discover his apprehensions, I said what was sufficient to tranquilize them; told him that the expedition was entirely broken up; and that we had known nothing of it, until we first heard of it from the Island of St. Bartholomew— He intimated a wish that we should give orders to our public vessels in the West-Indies against it, but I gave him no encouragement to expect that we would— Mr Canning as usual kept me till near dark— My family spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s, and I went in there towards the close of it, myself. The Tingeys, Wingates, R. Forrest’s, and W. S. Smith’s were there— Mrs Thornton and Mrs Wingate entertained us with the Piano; and with singing. I encountered the Doctor at Chess— I received this day a Letter from R. Walsh junr. of Philadelphia.

26. V. Note from the President directing a Meeting of the Members of the Administration at one O’Clock— Present, Mr Crawford, Mr Calhoun and Mr Thompson— The President read the draught prepared for his Message to Congress, at the opening of the Session of Congress. It is very long, and contains more of discussion than seemed to me suitable for such a paper.— The meeting was adjourned to half past one to-morrow, for reading it by paragraphs. Very few observations upon it were made this day— Calhoun proposed to substitute the words value of freight, for cost of freight, and I proposed the use of the term freight alone—which was sufficient to express the idea intended to be conveyed in the passage— The criticism in Calhoun’s objection to the term cost, was minute, but ingenious and just— It was in a paragraph concerning the comparative value of our exports and it had been drawn up by Crawford— The term cost, as thus applied to freight was incorrect, and Calhoun’s objection to it shewed that he was deeper in political Economy than Crawford— Mr Crawford objected to a passage concerning the decision of the Emperor of Russia, on the Ghent Treaty question— The President had said the Documents, including a Convention, to carry the decision into effect, would be communicated— Crawford thought this mode of expression would appear to imply that the Convention, had also been made by the Emperor— He had not heard of the Convention before— There was in the draught a very long paragraph upon the Military Academy at West-Point— I thought it occupied too large a space in the Message— I doubted whether any part of it was necessary; and there were in it a number of remarks upon the indocility and ardour of youthful minds of a nature too speculative, and doctrinal, for the occasion— I started the question first only upon these; and on the reperusal extended it, to the whole paragraph, with the exception of two or three sentences, sufficient to declare explicitly the President’s opinion in favour of maintaining the Institution: to check the disposition to abolish the institution, should it reappear, which was manifested in Congress at their last Session. Mr Crawford concurred with me in opinion, and observed that the remarks relating to the West Point Academy were the less necessary, as no measure was recommended to Congress in connection with them. He added that he thought there would be no attempt in Congress against the West-Point Academy at the next Session— That one member only, Coll. Cannon, had heretofore made efforts against it without success— I observed that besides this there had been at the last Session of Congress a Report of the Military Committee of the House against it, with some incorrect calculations of its expensiveness, to its disadvantage— Mr Crawford did not remember it— After we left the President’s Mr Calhoun came to my Office, and suggested a wish that I would not press the objection that I had opened to the paragraph in the Message concerning the West-Point Academy.— He said that the principle of objecting because no measure was recommended, could go great lengths to expunge much the greatest part of the Message, the object of which was adapted to the existing state of things; and the intention of the President was strongly to mark his opinions in support of the Institutions of the Country. I said I was not tenacious of the objection; but the message was very long; and remarks of general speculation upon the difficulty of keeping young men under proper discipline, did not seem to me to be there in their proper place. He said they might be omitted.
